dataset.title: Main Experiment: Leaf traits and chemicals from individual trees in the Main Experiment (Site A & B)

abstract.para: Leaf traits and chemicals from tree species in the Main Experimental sites, including secondary compound (total phenolic and tannin concentrations) and information on stomata.

keywordSet.keywordThesaurus: Find the list of keywords here: https://china.befdata.biow.uni-leipzig.de/keywords
List of headers of the data columns in this dataset

intellectualRights.para: Prof. Helge Bruelheide, David Eichenberg, Wenzel Kröber, Martin Böhnke, Christian Ristok

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Main Sites A and B of the experimantal plantations of BEF China 29°08'-29°11'N 117°90'-117°93'E

taxonomicCoverage.generalTaxonomicCoverage: Tree and shrub species planted in the Main experiment of BEF China

taxonomicClassification.commonName: Tree and shrub species planted in the Main experiment of BEF China

description.para: Main Experiment: Leaf traits and chemicals from individual trees in the Main Experiment (Site A & B)
Leaf traits and chemicals from tree species in the Main Experimental sites, including secondary compound (total phenolic and tannin concentrations) and information on stomata.
Main Sites A and B of the experimantal plantations of BEF China 29°08'-29°11'N 117°90'-117°93'E
Tree and shrub species planted in the Main experiment of BEF China

samplingDescription.para:
Leaf samples were taken from sun-exposed branches with an expandable pruner. Only completely developed leaves were sampled, without visible herbivore damage and preferably free of leaf fungi.
CAUTION: It seems that there has been a systematic error (maybe in the methodology?) in assessing some specific leaf traits (e.g. SLA) between the samples collected by W.Kröber and D.Eichenberg. Please bare this in mind!

dataTable.entityDescription: Main Experiment: Leaf traits and chemicals from individual trees in the Main Experiment (Site A & B)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The scientific species fullnames are based on the "Flora of China" identified by Teng Fang and verified by Helge Bruelheide (trees) and Alexandra Erfmeier (herbs). Scientific species names consist of epithet and genus. For identification, the Author name and the year of the publications of the description are required. (Species: Species name; Datagroup description: Scientific plant species name; Source: Flora of China; Datagroup description: Scientific plant species name)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Date time information, given as year or as date or as date time. (Year_Collected: Additional information on the year when the respective sample was collected; this allows for deciding, whether samples are dependent or independet (e.g. in time series anaysis), if the same individual was sampled in several years.; Datagroup description: Date time information)

textDomain.definition: Date time information, given as year or as date or as date time.

description.para: Date time information, given as year or as date or as date time.

Additional information on the year when the respective sample was collected; this allows for deciding, whether samples are dependent or independet (e.g. in time series anaysis), if the same individual was sampled in several years.; Datagroup description: Date time information

attribute.attributeDefinition: Helper column to understand other columns in this data set (Exp_Site: Indicator on which site of the Main Experiment (A or B) the Samples were collected)

description.para: Helper column to understand other columns in this data set
Indicator on which site of the Main Experiment (A or B) the Samples were collected

attribute.attributeDefinition: Helper column to understand other columns in this data set (Exp_vicinity: Some individuals were not sampled within a study plot, but e.g. in close vicinity to this plot. This column gives hints where the respective sample was collected.; Datagroup description: Some samples were not directly sampled within the experimental sites but were young recruits at the outer margin of the sites. This column gives information about where the sample was taken.)

textDomain.definition: Helper column to understand other columns in this data set

description.para: Helper column to understand other columns in this data set

Some individuals were not sampled within a study plot, but e.g. in close vicinity to this plot. This column gives hints where the respective sample was collected.; Datagroup description: Some samples were not directly sampled within the experimental sites but were young recruits at the outer margin of the sites. This column gives information about where the sample was taken.

attribute.attributeName: Plot name Main experiment (letter, number code) (Exp_Plot),
attribute.attributeDefinition: Plot number according to design spreadsheet. Plots are named according to their location on the original spreadsheet used for treatment design. This has letters from West to East and numbers from North to south. Some plots were moved half a gridcell (1 mu) so be suitable for planting (grid cell loctype). Example: B32 (Exp_Plot: Indiciating in which plot within respective the experimental site the sample was taken)

textDomain.definition: Plot number according to design spreadsheet. Plots are named according to their location on the original spreadsheet used for treatment design. This has letters from West to East and numbers from North to south. Some plots were moved half a gridcell (1 mu) so be suitable for planting (grid cell loctype). Example: B32

description.para: Plot name Main experiment (letter, number code)

Plot number according to design spreadsheet. Plots are named according to their location on the original spreadsheet used for treatment design. This has letters from West to East and numbers from North to south. Some plots were moved half a gridcell (1 mu) so be suitable for planting (grid cell loctype). Example: B32
Indiciating in which plot within respective the experimental site the sample was taken

attribute.attributeName: t or s TAG Main Experiment (TAG),
attribute.attributeDefinition: t-Tag/ s-Tag indicating individual tree position in the Main Experiment code for planting locations, 12 digits with "t" (tree) in front or "s" (shrub); Datagroup description: Tree or shrub tags consist of 12 digits: The first 6 are the site plot name: _1_ site _2/3_ row, counting from North _4/5_ column, counting from west _6_ is the plot moved? Is it a quarter plot? The next 6 digits describe the tree individual _7/8_ type of individual (01 planned tree, 02 other tree than planted but in a given plot somewhere, 03 planned shrub, 04 other shrub within this plot) _9/10_ x grid position within plot, starting from southwest northwards _11/12 y grid position, starting from southwest eastwards. (TAG: TAG of the respective tree individual in the main experiment)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Leaf stomata density (stomata.density: average Stomatal density)
Leaf stomata size (average.length: average Stomatal length)
Leaf stomata size (average.width: average Stomatal width)

Secondary metabolites are organic compounds that are not directly involved in the normal growth, development, or reproduction of an organism. Unlike primary metabolites, absence of secondary metabolites does not result in immediate death, but rather in long-term impairment of the organism's survivability, fecundity, or aesthetics, or perhaps in no significant change at all. Secondary metabolites often play an important role in plant defense against herbivory and other interspecies interactions (e.g. pollinator attraction). Examples of secondary metabolites are polyphenolic substances, flavonoids, terpenes etc. (Phenolics: total Phenolics content)

description.para: Secondary metabolites are organic compounds that are not directly involved in the normal growth, development, or reproduction of an organism. Unlike primary metabolites, absence of secondary metabolites does not result in immediate death, but rather in long-term impairment of the organism's survivability, fecundity, or aesthetics, or perhaps in no significant change at all. Secondary metabolites often play an important role in plant defense against herbivory and other interspecies interactions (e.g. pollinator attraction). Examples of secondary metabolites are polyphenolic substances, flavonoids, terpenes etc.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Secondary metabolites are organic compounds that are not directly involved in the normal growth, development, or reproduction of an organism. Unlike primary metabolites, absence of secondary metabolites does not result in immediate death, but rather in long-term impairment of the organism's survivability, fecundity, or aesthetics, or perhaps in no significant change at all. Secondary metabolites often play an important role in plant defense against herbivory and other interspecies interactions (e.g. pollinator attraction). Examples of secondary metabolites are polyphenolic substances, flavonoids, terpenes etc. (Tannin: total Tannin content expressed as mg/g tannic acid equivalents.)

description.para: Secondary metabolites are organic compounds that are not directly involved in the normal growth, development, or reproduction of an organism. Unlike primary metabolites, absence of secondary metabolites does not result in immediate death, but rather in long-term impairment of the organism's survivability, fecundity, or aesthetics, or perhaps in no significant change at all. Secondary metabolites often play an important role in plant defense against herbivory and other interspecies interactions (e.g. pollinator attraction). Examples of secondary metabolites are polyphenolic substances, flavonoids, terpenes etc.
total Tannin content expressed as mg/g tannic acid equivalents.

methodStep.instrumentation: Radial diffusion method for increased sensitivity as described in Hagerman 2002 "The tannin handbook" URL: http://www.users.miamioh.edu/hagermae/tannin.pdf
